content.webTitle: Q&A: Steve Price says Van Badham 'just being hysterical' about domestic violence

fields.headline: Q&A: Steve Price says Van Badham 'just being hysterical' about domestic violence
fields.bodyText: An anti-violence campaigner has accused Steve Price of excusing “misogynist comments” by broadcasters after the radio host told a fellow Q&A panellist she was being “hysterical” for linking the comments to violence against women. Tarang Chawla spoke of the brutal murder of his sister Nikita by her husband last year before asking the ABC talk show panel how “politicians and the media can play a better role in bringing about long overdue cultural shifts so tragedies like what happened to my family are not normalised”. Chawla prefaced his question by referring to the controversy around Eddie McGuire’s comments about “drowning” journalist Caroline Wilson and Sam Newman’s defence of McGuire. This prompted Price to again defend McGuire’s role in the episode, saying “Eddie apologised immediately” and that “too much was made of what was originally a joke on a football show”. A heated exchange that followed with Van Badham, a Guardian Australia columnist, provided the audience with the most provocative segment of the panel talk show. Topics canvassed before this ranged from the vulnerability of the newly elected prime minister, Malcolm Turnbull, to the foundations of Labor’s “Mediscare” campaign and whether the UK’s Chilcot inquiry showed parliament not cabinet should decide when to send Australia to war. Badham told Price that “what you see as jokes made by a bunch of blokes … from the position of being one of those blokes who’s probably been in on some of those jokes, I see as a woman who is part of a social world where violence is”. Price interrupted to ask she “retract” any suggestion “I have been in on one of those jokes” before agreeing he had described McGuire and others as “a bunch of blokes joking round and making apologies”. This was “fact”, he said, adding: “Don’t tar me with their brush, please.” Badham asked Price if he had “any understanding what you’re doing”. “This man has given us an extremely upsetting story about something that’s happened and you are defending yourself in the context where we have to have a conversation about cultural attitudes that treat women differently,” she said. Price provoked visible audience disquiet – including from Chawla – by telling Badham: “Just because you’re a woman, you’re not the only person who can get upset about this.” Badham in turn received audience applause by telling Price: “You are proving my point very excellently about the attitudes that create this kind of problem.” She said gender construction relegated women to lower status and “that we can make jokes and it’s all jokes and, oh yeah, they apologised and that’s fine but on the receiving end is the ludicrous proportion of women who do endure violence”. Price said Badham was “just being hysterical”, prompting gasps from the audience and her riposte: “It is probably my ovaries making me do it, Steve.” Chawla told Price he found some of his comments “rather offensive considering that you’re essentially sticking up for people making misogynist comments and passing them off as joking and banter”. “Do you not see yourself as having the ability to normalise views around gender equality? If so, how would you go about doing that?” Price, in a belated response to Chawla’s mention of his sister’s murder, said he felt “sorry for your personal circumstances but we can go too far in taking someone like a media personality and stringing them up”. “Eddie McGuire apologised, that should have been the end of the matter,” he said. The Coalition’s leader in the Senate, George Brandis, earlier defended the government’s election campaign amid questions over Turnbull’s ability to prevent an internal Liberal party split over lingering resentment among conservatives over Tony Abbott’s dumping. Brandis said he was confident the Coalition would secure a 77-seat majority, which was a “relatively narrow win but it is a clear win”. Price said his mainly conservative radio listeners resented the dumping of Abbott while the government’s proposed winding back of superannuation tax concessions had divided the Liberal support base. He said there was “a very real split” in the Liberal party and Turnbull needed to play “peacemaker” by bringing Abbott “back into the fold”. Brandis said Abbott was in the fold as an “elder statesman” of the party with “a lot to contribute” and there was no evidence he would undermine Turnbull. The deputy opposition leader, Tanya Plibersek, was forced to defend Labor’s campaign on the chances of Liberal dismantling or privatising further elements of Medicare, which the new Victorian senator elect Derryn Hinch described as “bullshit”. Hinch said fellow senator elect Pauline Hanson had drawn votes by playing to “anti-Muslim fears” rather than the economic insecurity of her base. “Pauline Hanson and I have two things in common ... that’s just about all — one, we’ve both been to prison and, two, we’ve both been on Dancing with the Stars,” he said. An Iraqi migrant, Michael Youssef, asked the panel what the US, UK and Australian governments should do “apart from apologise” in the wake of deaths in the Middle East following the toppling of Saddam Hussein. He later said, regardless of the pretext, the dictator’s removal was welcomed by the Iraqi people who had experienced oppression under his reign.
